Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2015 11:05AM - edited Apr 2, 2015 11:07AM by Romansma That 3rd episode was emotional for me to watch. I found it very hard to watch the female oncologist deliver the news to her patients, especially the older gentleman that had reached a point that he needed to enter hospice, most likely. Even though hard to watch, I agree with her style. Patients should be allowed to hope for the best, but should be prepared for the most likely outcome. As much as we'd like to think things have changed, for the most part, stage IV still means that it will most likely be the reason for our death. I cried in the segment about targeted treatments and how they haven't turned out to be the magic we hoped they would be, extending lives for a few months instead of lasting remissions. Although, I am hopeful, they can keep us around for the extra time needed to get to the next big thing in cancer research. Tempered optimism.

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2014 09:08AM - edited Sep 30, 2014 09:09AM by Romansma AC is the absolute worse!  I'm so sorry.  I told my husband, as I layed in bed motionless for days on end, that if I had to take AC indefinitely, I'd rather shoot myself in the head.  That said, Ativan helped ALOT!  It wasn't until my 3rd round that I got the Ativan....and I thought they were crazy giving me an anti anxiety med, but it really helped.  Also, stay ahead of dehydration and constipation....both can be epic on this combo.  Get some electrolyte water (Gatorade, yuck!) and start taking stool softness and maybe senna a couple times a day.  I wish you the best and I am so sorry you are feeling this way.

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2015 09:37PM Romansma wrote: Yes, weird flares of pain increasing for a week or so, then even stranger times (not as often) when the pain seems to take a break. I've had times where it steadily increased over a few weekS and later found it was due to progression of my bone mets. Other times, I have a flare for a few days, or a week. I think this might be due to my Xgeva shots that we have gone back to every 4 weeks, and when my calcium has been just barely enough. I don't take calcium as much as I should because it is constipating on top of the pain meds. This past week, I had a couple of mid day melt downs needing my pain meds. I usually take them around the clock. Then, out of the blue, a couple of days ago, I forgot to take one before bed and woke up the next morning feeling sorta ok. I still had pain, but I'd never get through the night normally. I've been able to cut back on the dose the last couple of days and I have no idea why. I'll take it!

Posts.Title: 5 reasons to stay alive diana50 PattyPeppermint

Posts.Content: Dec 19, 2014 08:43AM - edited Dec 19, 2014 08:47AM by Romansma I like this post! Here are mine! 1. My kids! My 10 yr old son that has the biggest heart I've ever seen! I want him to have a childhood he can look back on and smile about. The rest of my kids are older but still need guidance as they explore becoming adults and all the wonder and scariness it entails. Would love to stick around for another wedding or maybe grand baby 2. My husband. He's my best friend and we just go together. Who else can make me feel like I'm 12 again without a worry in the world! Also, I'd be too darn jealous to think someone else would come in to take my place 3. My close friends. I feel so lucky to have friends that have lifted me up when I needed it, provided for me and my family when we couldn't, and just let go and act silly without the worry of judgement. It's the kind of close friends you have when you are young, but we aren't young anymore! 4. My community friends. They have been so giving. It brings me to tears thinking about how giving and generous they have been. I know they want the best for me and there are not many ways to express that. They have expressed it loud and clear with their generosity! 5. Travel. I have planned some trips over the next 6 months and I want to be able bodied to enjoy every minute!

Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2014 09:11AM Romansma wrote: Interesting thought about whether it's the medicine or being 'cared for' by another human being.  I've talked to many women who have fought breast cancer and there seems to be some commonality in their experiences in childhood.  I know, in my adulthood, I've yearned to really be taken care of since so many of my emotional needs were unmet as a child.  My adult life has been full of good things, as well as many challenges.  I learned to 'parent' myself from a very early age and I think that made me appear to be strong in my adult life, which tends to make those in your life think you don't need their help.  Hard to explain, but interesting to think that there may be a link.  I think the mind and body are linked in more ways than we ever imagined.  I wish it didn't take a metastatic diagnosis to become aware of it.

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2013 02:36AM Romansma wrote: Bestbird recently posted some information on this: Bestbird wrote: Musa Mayer of bcmets.org kindly posted a synopsis of therapies for ER+ mbc as per the latest info gleaned from the San Antonio conference. It clearly depicts the various therapies, and ends with this helpful reminder. From:advancedbc.org/files/SABCS_Hal... "Don’t forget to go back to endocrine therapy! One of the most common suggestions we (at Dana Farber) make for patients with initially hormone sensitive MBC who have had multiple lines of chemotherapy is to revisit the endocrine therapies, even in late stage disease. “We probably don’t reintroduce endocrine therapy frequently enough.” So what does the sequence of endocrine therapies look like in December 2013? For those patients who are endocrine naïve, or who’ve had little endocrine therapy: if they’re premenopausal, in the first line, it’s a combination of ovarian function suppression and tamoxifen. If they’re postmenopausal, I’m intrigued by data suggesting that combination therapy works particularly well in patients who have not had prior therapy, so I look at that SWOG data and am tempted to use an aromatase inhibitor with fulvestrant. In the second line, if there has been treatment with prior tamoxifen and/or an AI, fulvestrant is indicated. In 3rd line, consider an AI + an mTOR inhibitor, and when that fails, progestins, estrogens, or move on to chemotherapy."

Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2014 09:32PM - edited Jun 15, 2014 09:34PM by Romansma I went to see "The Fault in our Stars" with my husband this weekend.  My youngest just turned 10 and I know this is a movie he isn't ready for.  I agree wholeheartedly agree with being honest with our kids while taking into consideration what they are ready for.  My youngest knows that my cancer has come back and I have also told him it can't be cured any longer, that I will always have it.  So, when I am told that the time is near, I will tell him.  My thought process is that will happen at least a few months before, if not about 6 months before I die.  I want him to have time to process, but I don't want him to have to deal with something that he is too young to process right now, especially because, if one of these treatments works, it could be years away.  I share this only as a point of view, knowing there are other points of view and there are no right or wrong ways to do this.  Each child is different, and their readiness to deal with such adult issues doesn't happen at a given age.

Posts.Content: Sep 3, 2014 10:15AM Romansma wrote: Just checking in for a minute before I go make breakfast and pack lunches.  My 10 yr old went to see Guardians of the Galaxy with his dad.  My DH told me there was a tough scene in the beginning that a boy loses his mother, in the hospital, bald head and all.  He said he watched our son to see his reaction and didn't see one.  Whew, crisis averted.  Then, 5 days later, around 10:30, our son came into our room, tapped me and asked if I could come talk to him.  We went to the sofa and he was full of tears.  He told me that he had a nightmare, that I died in the hospital.  Right away, I knew the movie had influenced him.  We talked about the movie, his feelings and fears and I explained that I could not predict the future, but for now I am ok.  We also talked about worry and how it can rob you of enjoying your time and the people you love right now.  Then, we read from a favorite book and I slept in his room.   So, lesson learned.  Next time, we will not ignore the elephant in the room.  We will talk about it, as uncomfortable as it is.  Sometimes kids fears are right on......and why should they have to deal with them all alone?

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2014 05:11AM Romansma wrote: I've been following along and first, I'd like to say......I'll take either!  I think these terms are used interchangeably by most, whether that's right or wrong.  I am following someone that recently found out she is NED unexpectedly (might be the same person).  I think she has been forthright in her hope that it is for a long time, but she has shared that she realizes this state could change at any moment.  She is still being actively treated.  I think this is a healthy attitude.  Being hopeful can go a long ways towards living life for all it has to give.  I recently had a scan that was a bit mixed, but I had regression in areas.  I chose to take this as good news and to share it that way too.  I let those that need to know more that I will never be cured, even if the scans show nothing.  But, I was surprised at how this scan, and sharing the results with those around me, had an impact on the way I was thinking and feeling.  I had more hope for my future than I had felt in a year, maybe longer.   So, maybe sharing some good news can be just the attitude adjustment needed.  I think most women with breast cancer understand that stage IV is almost never cured.  Up to this point, I've been the "realistic" stage IV girl that knows the odds are not good.  Seeing her post made me think......maybe that could be me!  It helped me to continue on with treatments that I was thinking before, "what's the use, they never work".  For once, I'm living up to my given name....Hope.

Posts.Content: May 28, 2012 01:52AM Romansma wrote: I just finished reading this thread. Thank you to everyone that has contributed. I wake up each morning looking for something to make my tail wag, even though I feel deep down that this disease is somewhere planning it's next attack on me. I guess I found out how much of a numbers gal I really am after I got knocked off my chair reading my path report. I know there's a good chance We nailed it, but for me, there's just as good a chance that we didn't. I live a healthy lifestyle, while still enjoying myself. I refuse to beat myself up about enjoying this life.......as long or short as it may be. I have fears too.....that my 8 year old son will have to grow up without me......that I won't get to be there when my 20 year old daughter gets married, or has my first grand baby......even, hating the thought of my husband getting close to some other woman after I'm gone. But, enjoying myself and my family is a win win in my book. If I'm around for all that stuff it will be something better than I can describe here with my words. If I'm not here, my family will have some really wonderful memories of our time together instead of remembering how mom was turned inward with fear. Let's not lie to ourselves about the anxiety that we feel and how it affects our loved ones. I, for one am trying to turn all that energy to more positive places, while I still can!

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2014 11:15AM Romansma wrote: I think we are programmed to think ahead.....a survival technique of sorts.  Kinda works against us at times like this, though.  Yesterday was a good day for me.  Scans all day with lots of time in the tube and waiting while the dyes took affect.  Because I had met with an inspiring 15 year Stage IV survivor the day before, I was feeling some hope.  I did a lot of meditating and my mind kept finding all the really great things that I've experienced in the last few months, even though this big C thing was present.  I envisioned a fork in the road and how I kept trying to go to the left where it lead me to seeing my kids grow up and growing old myself.  But that path had a road block and only led to frustration.  So instead I envisioned the road to the right and once on that path I could see all the beauty that was right here every day.  I topped it off with a cranked up sing along in the car ride home to the Rolling Stones You Can't Always Get What You Want.  Cried a little.  But I get what I need!

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2015 08:08PM - edited Feb 24, 2015 08:10PM by Romansma Rosevalley, I failed ALL the hormonals and my Ibrance is being delivered today. I'm hoping side effects are not awful. Quality is very important to me. Afinitor was no walk in the park. I had awful mouth sores, ankle swelling, neuropathy, and more. But none of the effects went on forever, they would eventually resolve. I was on Afinitor for 10 months and it probably stopped working around month 7. I can't remember who asked about Xeloda, but I don't think it worked at all for me. My tumor markers have continued to rise. That said, I didn't give it much of a chance. I was on it for about 9 weeks before deciding the side effects were too much for me. Holly, I think choosing no treatment is a valid option that is not considered often enough. We all want to be in that elite club of exceptional responders, but many of us won't be lucky that way. Many of the drugs we take are only giving an extra 2-3 months overall survival benefit, if any at all. Weighed against side effects, it's not always worth it. Our doctors have these drugs as their main tool for treatment and won't usually mention no treatment as an option unless you bring it up. I have brought it up at a couple of junctures and been told it was a viable option considering my situations.

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2014 12:18PM Romansma wrote: Yes, I'm feeling a little selfish and clingy myself.  I don't want to be away from him for a week.  I have high hopes for adventure this summer.  I know my treatments will get harder and my body will get weaker.  Next summer can't be guaranteed. He seems to be in a hurry to go thru puberty and keeps asking when it will happen for him. Btw, he just turned 10.  He's really tall and I think he wants a deep voice to match his tallness.  Yesterday, he also asked when we should have 'the talk'.  He is the youngest of 5, and I think he wants to grow up a little faster because of all his older brothers and sisters.  I was happy he asked, because I LOVE being here for his milestones.  I got to tell him how I felt about certain things that don't come up in everyday conversations.  Birds and bees were all over the car!  He didn't say much, but I could tell the gears in his brain were working overtime.  Not only will he remember this 'talk' with his mom, but it opens up a conversation we can continue to have.  I thought I might have to write to him to share some of this with him because he wouldn't be ready for it before I'm gone.  We finished the day with some egg coloring.  Good day! My oldest son's grad announcements came yesterday.  I am jumping out of my skin excited for him to graduate.  We also met with the counselor at a tech school that he plans to attend before going on to college in the spring of next year.  We are working on a scholarship application.  I'm am so excited for him! My oldest daughter got some tough news this week.  She is 22.  She went in for a baseline mammogram to start the surveillance.  She has had a cyst that we have watched for a few years now. However, the ultrasound turned up 2 solid tumors, one in each breast.  It sent me into a spin.  Logically, they are more than likely benign.  But, it drove home how much stress this will be for her for decades to come.  The biopsies are scheduled for the end of the month. It's a bright, sunshiny, day and I intend to get out in it....dig in the dirt, and enjoy my yard.  The wild flowers are starting to bloom on my hillside (I cheated a little and threw seed on it about 6 weeks ago, but shhhhhhhh).

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2014 09:36AM Romansma wrote: Just wanted to let all you moms know that I feel for you.  This boat we all sit in is a bit unstable and we all have to find ways to make it work.  I, too, am trying to find ways to be present with my family in spite of the pain, side effects, and fatigue.  Don't put too much pressure on yourself to be the perfect mom.  Rest, and take care of yourself, mind, body, and spirit.  When you fill up your own tank it's so much easier to be fully present for your kids and spouse or partner.  I'm no expert on this, but I've seen what happens when I don't give myself what I need first.  It all falls apart.  I'm too tired, or in pain....which leads to cranky mom syndrome....which tends to make the entire family cranky.  Anyway, you all know this, I'm sure!  This weekend, our kids and dogs will fend for themselves while my husband and I have a weekend away to celebrate our anniversary.  It's tough to leave them, but it was him and I before it was mom and dad and we need a little time to connect the way we did before all the wonderful mayhem.  Weekends like this help me to feel supported by my husband and continue that closeness that helps us both deal with this disease and the worry of what is to come.  Hang in there everyone.  Do or plan something that is all about you and your needs as an individual.  It will go a long way towards allowing you to be present with your children.

Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2014 10:24AM - edited Dec 7, 2014 10:27AM by Romansma I've purposely stayed away from this thread for awhile. It made living in denial so much easier. This is my biggest fear. Patty, I'm sorry you weren't able to have lunch with your son. We've talked about this before. For them, they just want us to be there. They aren't able to distinguish quality vs. quantity. As mothers, we walk a tight rope of concern with our quality of life, but at the same time, lengthening it to allow our kids to be a little older, a bit more mature when they ultimately deal with losing us. Give yourself a break and just go have lunch when you feel better. Kids are resilient. Don't beat yourself up. KJones....get someone over to help you! If not a paid service, a friend or relative. Don't feel guilty, just accept the help. It will lift the burden and you will be able to enjoy the holidays more

Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2014 10:51AM Romansma wrote: My 10 year old doesn't know the whole truth about my cancer either.  I have told him the cancer is back and a few months later, I explained that I would always have the cancer and it was not going to go away.  But, it is too early to tell him how this ends.  I am working with my psychologist on this and she is in agreement that letting him have his childhood for as long as possible is very important.  When the time comes, I will tell him.  I want him to have time to process and be part of everything that happens, but not yet.  He is very sensitive and empathic and I think, on some level, he already knows.  But for now, my little 4th grader is having his "best school year, so far" in his own words, and that tells me that I'm doing the right thing! That said, I think all kids are different, and some may need to know earlier.  We all know our kids, and we are the best one to determine how much they can handle.  My older kids know, and they are doing well, but they need help processing too.  Both have had counseling.  I talk to them too, but not too much.  In little doses.  Then we get back to fun and life. I read The Fault in our Stars and I plan to go see the movie.  I'm not sure I'd want any of my kids to see it.  However, if they really wanted to see it, I don't think I'd stop them.  They'd really be curious if I tried to keep it from them.  Might make a good reason to talk about life, death, and all the good stuff in between.

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2014 11:44AM - edited Jul 17, 2014 11:46AM by Romansma Such great ideas here.  I like the list, the artist date,  trip planning, and music in your favorite chair with a pair of headphones does wonders!  I wish I could say I never worry much, I envy you, Chrissy.  My kids are my distraction most days.....and my source of anxiety about the future.  I've found that guided meditation (with those same headphones) is helpful.  Just being mindful of your breath, the here and now, relaxes you enough to start thinking clearly again.  Also, I started using guided imagery while I was going through radiation to my upper spine earlier this year.  Having my head and shoulders bolted down to a table daily was some sort of mideival torture in my mind.  Using my imagination to take myself to the beach or redwoods got me through the daily torture.  I use it during scns too.

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2014 11:36AM Romansma wrote: I'm so sorry.  I'm not sure I have a lot of advice since I'm pretty new at this too.  My youngest cried when I told him I had cancer again.  Actually, all of my kids did.  I told them each individually because their ages are so different.  My youngest doesn't yet know the severity of my diagnosis.  I will tell him more as things progress.  However, he was sensitive for some time, worried about everything I did and asked if I should be doing certain things.  I kept talking to him letting him know I was ok and that I didn't want him worrying all the time.  He has gotten more carefree, but I know he is still keeping a close eye on me.  I think it's just something you take in small bits and pieces....keep talking to him....letting him know how much you want to enjoy his company today.  My youngest has started coming up with lists of things we should do together (he is 9).  Maybe helping your 11 yr old switch the focus to creating memories and planning for things he wants to experience with you would be a start.

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2014 07:26AM - edited Apr 27, 2014 07:29AM by Romansma I don't see this thread as hate.  An opinion is being shared about a statement made by someone in the public eye.  This statement is one of the things that is perpetuated by so many well meaning people when it comes to cancer.  But it is false, and more so, demeaning to those that lose their lives to cancer.  I don't watch GMA, but I hope the best for this person.  I hope she never has to to face her children and let them know the cancer is back and will never again leave....a day like that makes you tough....but the cancer still wins in the end.  I also hope that she realizes soon that way tougher people than her die everyday.  I hope she uses her celebrity to get that fact out there and effect change.  Effect change for organizations like Komen that contribute such a small share of the obscene amount of dollars raised to research on MBC.

Posts.Content: May 31, 2015 09:02AM - edited May 31, 2015 09:05AM by Romansma Good morning to you. I am so sorry you are feeling so hopeless. Some things about your post grabbed me. First, when you said your bone mets were visible on MRI only, I wondered if you had ILC. I checked your diagnosis, and yes, you do. I have ILC too, and MRI was the only way anything was visible in the beginning, and now, when things spread. That said, Petscans so light up for me now, but just the areas that have grown large enough to show in that mode. I say all this, because your tumor load may still be low if you are still only showing on MRI. That's good. Another thing, were they able to biopsy your liver tumors? I really think this is important because the biological markers may have changed from your original tumor. Bone mets aren't great for showing these changes. There have been numerous ladies on BCO that found out their ILC had become Her2 positive after spreading to soft tissue. This would be very important to know since there are very effective treatments for this. Teakie's experience with become NED is not all that uncommon. How great would that be to wake up one day and know you had beat this cancer bugger back? There are so many reasons to believe that you still have many years left. Your son still needs you and yes, he'd be fine without you, but he'd be so much better with you! My youngest son was 6 and had just started first grade when I was diagnosed with stage 3 ILC. My cancer returned in my bones when he was in 3rd grade. He just turned 11 and will start middle school next year. It has all been worth it. The older he gets, the better I feel that he will be able to deal with what life throws at him. He will also take a piece of me into his adult life and carry me with him. That gives me so much peace. Why bother? Because each day holds the promise that something very good could happen!
